Award.AwardTitle: RUI: CMI: Effect of solution conditions and analyte properties on negative ion electrospray ionization
Award.AbstractNarration: With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professors Christine Hughey and Stephen Lucas and their groups will explore the fundamentals of negative ion electrospray ionization, an ionization technique that selectively charges acidic molecules by deprotonation prior to mass spectrometric detection. Specifically, the researchers will investigate the mechanisms of ionization under different pH regimes and develop a multivariate model that will predict response for physiochemically diverse acidic analytes under different solution/pH conditions. In pursuit of these objectives, the team will test the hypothesis that analyte physiochemical properties have a greater impact on ionization efficiency than the route of ion formation. Since James Madison University is a predominately undergraduate institution (PUI), undergraduate chemistry and mathematics majors will conduct the research proposed and, in doing so, will learn how to effectively collaborate and communicate across disciplines. In addition, Professors Hughey and Lucas have a demonstrated track record with the involvement of women and the deaf in their research. The groups will continue to be an integral part of the research project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to predict an analyte's response from its physiochemical properties provides valuable insight into how an analytical instrument works and, subsequently, how to optimize methods of analysis for that instrument. Here we measured the response of 100+ small, acidic molecules with diverse physiochemical properties with the aim of developing a model to predict their ionization efficiency in negative ion electrospray ionization (ESI). Negative ion ESI is used to convert neutral analytes to negatively charged ions for mass spectrometric detection. Analytes used in this study were selected for their relevance in routine biological, environmental and food analyses. In addition, analytes from five compound classes (benzoic acids, phenols, thiols, acetanilides and indoles) were systematically substituted to determine how response changed as a function of compound class and solvent system. Solvent systems investigated included methanol, methanol:water and methanol:water with six different modifiers (e.g., weak acids, weak bases and volatile salts). Collectively, more than 5,000 measurements were made in flow injection experiments on a triple quadrupole mass spectrometer.

Numerous approaches were taken to build a model to predict negative ion ESI response. Correlations between physiochemical properties (up to 28 properties were considered) and response were investigated across all 100+ compounds, across the five compounds classes and within a single compound class. The use of single variable regression, multiple linear regression (MLR) and support vector machine (SVM) was investigated. The strongest correlations were observed within a compound class (e.g., benzoic acids or n-carboxylic acids). However, correlations across all 100+ compounds were weak. Subsequently, we set out to reproduce a model published in Analytical Chemistry (2014, 86, 4822-4830) that successfully predicted response for phenols and benzoic acids. After consultation with the original authors, we were able to reproduce their model and are in the process of publishing those results. Reproduction the model also provided insight into how we can improve our model, which includes a more diverse set of compounds.

We also investigated the effect of commonly used liquid chromatography modifiers on negative ion response. We found that high responding compounds were less affected by the presence of a modifier compared to low responding compounds. The response of low responding compounds, such as indoles, was improved in the presence of ammonium fluoride.

For undergraduates, research experience is the best tool for training and professional development. It affords them the opportunity to apply their classroom knowledge to solve new analytical problems, where the outcome is not predetermined (as is often the case in coursework laboratory experiments). A total of six JMU students worked on the project. Most students worked on the project for more than two years. In addition, four undergraduates from the University of the Pacific calculated the gas phase properties of model compounds. JMU students involved in this project learned to design experiments, analyze and interpret data and present their data a local or national meetings. Cumulatively, their work was presented at five regional and national scientific meetings, including the Southeastern Regional Meeting of the American Chemical Society and the Annual Conference on Mass Spectrometry and Allied Topics. They also presented their work every spring and summer at symposia organized by the Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry at JMU. Two publications are in preparation.

Half of the students who worked on this project decided to pursue a graduate degree in analytical chemistry as a direct result of their research experience afforded by this RUI grant. Two of the three students pursued graduate research in mass spectrometry. All students who worked on the project remained in STEM fields. Students that pursued graduate work went to Texas A&M, Colorado State and NC State. Other students entered the workforce as a pharmacy technician and a computer programmer.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2019
Modified by: Christine A Hughey
